Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider that's really an off the charts kind of spike- rechecking next month seems to be a good idea. a urologist would be likely just order another psa test as well- make sure its correct. cancer is very unlikely to have caused that kind of increase. I read something about PSA velocity and that it it shoots up more than .5ng/mL in less than a year it a sign of PC. Don't have the link, been looking around crazy for this. Especially since my grandfather and one of my uncles had PC around the same age
Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Not sure about that, Chris. But prostate infections DO put pretty good spikes into the PSA number. It really is VERY unlikely that such a short term spike would be caused by prostate cancer. It is far more likely to be prostatitis, something that can be cured with medicine. Good luck! Chuck I will look into this more Chuck, I had no idea about prostatitis and other things, thanks. I was able to talk to my dad and he seems a lot more relaxed about this whole thing (if it is or it's PC) then I am (Due of our family history with PC).
Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Content: My dad (age: 70) went in for another blood work and his PSA level jumped up to 4.8ng/mL. Spike in PSA level - 2/17/17: 0.537ng/mL - 8/11/17: 4.8ng/mL His doctor is ordering another PSA test next month because he's worried about the spike, as am I. Should we just go to a Urologist and not wait?
Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Chris! 4 Questions: - Why did your father at age 70 have an Ultrasensitive PSA (so it appears) test? - Did his URO MD have any explanation as to why it was so low back in Feb? - At such a low level, why did he have his PSA repeated 6 months later? - Has he been previously treated for either PCa or other prostate issues? TY MF - He got the test with his GP haven't seen the URO yet - He went in for his yearly physical on Feb and they took his PSA along with other blood work. They repeated the whole test again (all blood work) because his blood sugar was a lot higher than normal (He has type 2 diabetes). So when the test results came back and his PSA level hiked the doctor said he wanted to repeat it. - His PSA levels have alway been that low...never above 1.0ng/mL - no he's never had any type of prostate issues
Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA velocity is a sign of possible cancer. But the kind of increase that dad had (7 fold in 6 months) would more likely be an infection. Cancer doesn't usually multiply PSA like that. Had no idea infections could affect PSA level, but wouldn't an infection affect the other level from his blood work he got?
